docs.lead_paragraph: The rate at which men were killed by their wives or companions fell by close to two-thirds over the last 20 years, according to a new report published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. The rate at which women were killed by what the researchers called ''intimate partners'' also fell, by almost a third, although that reduction essentially mirrored the overall decline in the nation's homicide rate in the study period of 1981 to 1998. Over all, women represented close to two-thirds of the victims.
docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that rate at which men are killed by their wives or companions has fallen by close to two-thirds over last 20 years and that rate at which women are killed by their 'intimate partners' has fallen by almost a third; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A drug normally given to cancer patients appears to help people with heart disease by promoting the growth of new blood vessels that form a natural bypass around blocked arteries, according to a study in the journal Circulation. The study, led by Dr. Christian Seiler of University Hospital in Bern, Switzerland, looked at a drug called GM-CSF, which is used to help maintain white blood cell counts in people receiving chemotherapy.

headline.main: Building a Bypass Road of Blood Vessels

docs.abstract: GM-CSF, drug normally given to cancer patients, is shown to help people with heart disease by promoting growth of new blood vessels that form natural bypass around blocked arteries (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: While millions of Americans fret over the threat of anthrax spread by terrorists, they may ignore another infectious disease that will soon descend on the country and probably claim tens of thousands of lives. That disease is influenza. And while an anthrax vaccine is not available to the general public, a flu vaccine is, and it can prevent a vast majority of cases of influenza and the death and disability they can cause. In a typical year, 10 percent to 20 percent of Americans come down with influenza, 200,000 people are hospitalized and more than 20,000 die from flu-related complications. Most of this can be prevented by a shot that costs $10 to $15.

headline.main: An Easy Means of Prevention: A Flu Shot

docs.abstract: Doctors raise serious questions about giving weekly doses of steroids to pregnant women who are at risk of starting labor too early and having premature babies; drugs can decrease risk of life-threatening complications in premature babies, but many obstetricians have been giving their patients higher amounts than have been studied, and evidence is mounting that overusing drugs can sometimes cause serious consequences in mothers and their babies, with little or no added benefit; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors are raising serious questions about a practice that has become commonplace: giving weekly doses of steroids to pregnant women who are at risk of starting labor too early and having premature babies. The problem is not steroids per se: research has shown that the drugs can decrease the risk of life-threatening complications in premature babies. But many obstetricians have been giving their patients higher amounts than have been studied, and evidence is mounting that overusing the drugs can sometimes cause serious consequences in mothers and their babies, with little or no benefit.

headline.main: New Doubts About Treatment for Premature Babies

docs.lead_paragraph: Although several new techniques have been developed for diagnosing appendicitis, the number of unnecessary operations has not decreased, a new study in The Journal of the American Medical Association says. Appendicitis is often difficult to distinguish from other forms of acute abdominal pain. Surgeons, the article said, have always accepted that doing a certain number of unnecessary operations was preferable to allowing the inflammation to progress to the point that the appendix bursts, causing a far more serious abdominal infection.

headline.main: A Bad Appendix Remains Hard to Spot

docs.abstract: Number of unnecessary appendectomies does not decrease despite advent of new methods of distinguishing appendicitis from other forms of acute abdominal pain; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: People who use the drug Ecstasy appear to suffer long-term memory damage even after they give it up, a new study from the Netherlands concludes. The study, published last week in The Archives of General Psychiatry, compared 22 recent Ecstasy users, 16 people who said they had used the drug but not for at least a year, and 13 people who had never taken it.

headline.main: Down the Road, Drug May Still Do Harm

docs.abstract: People who use drug Ecstasy are found to suffer long-term memory damage even after they give it up; brain scans in recent usets show signs of damage to mechanisms associated with serotonin, particularly in area of brain linked to memory (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers who spent nine months examining what students left on their lunch plates concluded that the best way to get children to eat their spinach was to make the portions smaller in the rest of the meal. The researchers, from Columbus Children's Hospital in Ohio, found that children ate the same amount of the meal on their plates -- on average, 67 percent -- no matter what the entree was.

headline.main: In School Lunches, It's All Proportional

docs.abstract: Researchers find that best way to get children to eat fruits and vegetables in their school lunches is to reduce portions in rest of meal; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as New Yorkers flinched at every new mention of anthrax last week and fought rising panic, the regular Monday meeting of the city's infectious disease specialists unfolded more or less as usual. True, there were two cases of anthrax in the city, possibly more. But there was also a case of cholera here last spring. An unusual, near-fatal case of the dire food poisoning known as listeriosis surfaced over the summer. A young German man picked up a peculiar, disfiguring case of H.I.V. A businessman came down with a bizarre fungal infection on the golf course. A Mexican deliveryman almost died from inhaling a rare soil organism common in Central America.

headline.main: For Some, Anthrax Falls To the B-List

docs.abstract: Regular weekly meeting of New York City's infectious disease specialists unfolds more or less as usual, as hypothetical threat of anthrax seems to fade a little against panorama of microbes that routinely appear in city; not one of 150 doctors attending meeting is seriously worried that tide of infection is about to drown city, and most seem more concerned with what they see as rising tide of unnecessary anthrax panic (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a tiny stage: a 10-by-12-foot room. The cast is also tiny: two players. The props include an examination table, a sink, some drawers, a blood pressure gauge and other medical instruments. And though the performers will not earn rave (or any) reviews in tomorrow's newspaper, they both know that how well they play their roles could someday make the difference between someone's life and death. The scene is the emergency room of the Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. The patient, a 22-year-old African-American man named Marcus Holter, is lying on the bed, convincingly writhing in pain. The doctor is Tomer Begaz, a 26-year-old fourth-year medical student.

headline.main: Medical Students Get Taste of Real-Life Doctoring

docs.abstract: 'Standardized patients,' actors and other trained to portray sick people, simulate disease symptoms for students in mock examinaton rooms at medical schools across the country; future doctors hone their diagnostic skills and learn how to talks to patients, to listen and to be compassionate; photo (M)
